title: A Case of Mistaken Identity
chief_complaint: I have constant imbalance and pressure in my left ear, and I've noticed hearing loss on that side. My eyes seem to 'jump' when I hear loud sounds like the telephone ringing, and I feel a rattle or vibration in my head when I talk.

problem_summary.onset: 20-year history of symptoms; evaluated 7 months prior at another facility.
problem_summary.course: Chronic symptoms including fullness, ringing, and imbalance. Previously diagnosed with Ménière disease but symptoms did not fluctuate or occur in spells.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral findings, though patient reports primary symptoms in the Left ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tullio phenomenon (eyes jumping with loud sound), autophony (voice rattling in head), constant imbalance.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Avoidance of loud sounds; concern about hearing aids due to eye movement response.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking second opinion and relief from imbalance/hearing issues.

history.present_illness: Patient seen for second opinion after being diagnosed with left Ménière disease 7 months prior. Reports constant imbalance, pressure, and hearing loss in left ear. Reports Tullio phenomenon (eyes jump with loud noise) and autophony.
history.otologic_history: 20-year history of fullness and ringing in left ear.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Mild to moderate mixed loss rising to normal at 8000 Hz with significant air-bone gaps (15-20 dB) at low frequencies. Left ear: Slight to mild mixed loss sloping to moderately severe at 8000 Hz with a 30 dB air-bone gap at 250 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition thresholds mildly impaired bilaterally. Word recognition scores excellent/within normal limits.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally, suggesting normal middle ear function despite air-bone gaps.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral reflexes present and normal bilaterally (unexpected for conductive loss). Contralateral reflexes mostly normal, slightly elevated at specific frequencies.

tests.name: Electrocochleography (ECoG)
tests.key_findings: Summating potential (SP) to action potential (AP) amplitude ratios were enlarged bilaterally (>0.5), consistent with SSCD.

tests.name: Vestibular Evaluation
tests.key_findings: VOG normal. Calorics symmetric (8% left weakness - normal). Rotary chair normal. CDP showed decreased vestibular utilization (falls on SOT 5 & 6).

tests.name: Spiral CT Scan
tests.key_findings: Confirmed dehiscence of the superior semicircular canal bilaterally.

history.present_illness: Patient returned to discuss hearing aid options after declining surgical management. Expressed concern about loud sounds causing eye movement.
history.patient_goals: Trial hearing aid in left ear.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Fit with 15-channel digital BTE with slim tube and open dome. Verified to NAL-NL1 targets. Directional microphone performance verified.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral mixed hearing loss characterized by low-frequency air-bone gaps, yet paradoxically normal tympanometry and present acoustic reflexes. ECoG testing revealed significantly enlarged SP/AP ratios bilaterally. CT imaging confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD), explaining the 'third window' effect responsible for the hypersensitive bone conduction and vestibular symptoms.
counseling_points: Your symptoms (imbalance, hearing your own voice loudly, eyes jumping with noise) are caused by a thinning of the bone in the inner ear canal, known as Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD), not Ménière's disease.
The 'gap' on your hearing test is due to your inner ear being hypersensitive to bone-conducted sound, rather than a problem with your middle ear bones.
Hearing aids can help with the hearing loss, but we must be careful with volume to avoid triggering your dizziness or eye movements.
Surgical options exist to plug the canal, but since you have chosen to defer surgery, we will monitor your hearing and balance annually.
notes_for_actor: Portray anxiety specifically regarding loud sounds; mention that the phone ringing makes your eyes feel like they are jumping.
Describe your voice as sounding 'rattling' or vibrating inside your head (autophony).
You are skeptical about hearing aids because you worry making things louder will trigger your dizziness/eye symptoms.
